steps.reason_ready: After exhaustive evaluation—serial normal MRI/DWI and MR angiography of the posterior circulation, normal comprehensive vestibular testing (bedside HIT, vHIT, calorics, rotatory chair, cVEMP/oVEMP), normal audiometry, absence of focal neurologic deficits or vascular risk factors—the most likely diagnosis is vestibular migraine (probable) presenting with acute spontaneous persistent vertigo. Atypical post-viral vestibulopathy (vestibular neuritis) is less likely given lack of objective unilateral vestibular hypofunction, and posterior circulation stroke is unlikely given repeated negative imaging and low vascular risk.
steps.synthesis_prompt:
You are a medical diagnosis synthesizer. Based on all the information gathered during a clinical evaluation, provide a single, specific final diagnosis.

## Information Gathered:
- Patient presents with dizziness, nausea, and imbalance.
- Vital signs normal: Temperature 98.7°F, BP 122/81 mmHg, HR 82 bpm, RR 15/min, SpO2 99% on room air.
- Onset this morning with constant spinning sensation (continuous vertigo) since onset, not episodic or triggered by head movements; occasional nausea.
- Patient reports no hearing loss, tinnitus, or ear pain, and denies headache, double vision, limb weakness, numbness, slurred speech, or difficulty swallowing.
- HINTS exam: Head Impulse test normal, Nystagmus observed (type not specified), Test of Skew normal.
- MRI brain diffusion-weighted imaging shows no acute abnormalities; no evidence of acute ischemia or structural lesion.
- Patient reports a cold a few days ago and increased garlic intake; denies history of migraine.
- Basic audiometry: bilateral decreased hearing sensitivity.
- Full diagnostic audiometry (pure-tone air and bone conduction), speech discrimination, and tympanometry are normal.
- Video head impulse test (vHIT) and ENG/VNG including caloric testing returned normal readings.
- Patient reports no vascular risk factors (no hypertension, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, or smoking), is not on anticoagulant/antiplatelet therapy, and has had no transient focal neurological symptoms (no vision changes, slurred speech, weakness, or numbness) since vertigo onset.
- Neuro exam: spontaneous nystagmus present; bedside bilateral decreased hearing reported; unstable tandem gait but baseline gait largely unremarkable; finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin normal; Romberg normal.
- Repeat MRI brain with diffusion-weighted imaging and MR angiography of the posterior circulation returned normal — no acute ischemia or vascular abnormality.
- Patient denies current headache, photophobia, phonophobia, visual aura, and has no family history of migraine.
- Symptoms have stayed the same since onset this morning — constant low-grade spinning with occasional nausea; diphenhydramine helped slightly; no prior similar episodes.
- Patient reports no new prescription medications or recreational drugs, no recent alcohol, no head trauma, no ear fullness, and no perceived change in hearing since symptom onset; has taken diphenhydramine which provides slight symptomatic relief.
- Repeat MRI brain with diffusion-weighted imaging performed 24-48 hours after onset is normal (no acute ischemia or vascular abnormality).
- Rotatory chair testing (complete vestibular function testing, including sinusoidal harmonic acceleration and VEMP if available) returned normal readings.
- Cervical and ocular VEMP testing returned normal readings.

## Task:
Provide a single, specific diagnosis (1-3 words). Examples:
- "Acute appendicitis"
- "Community-acquired pneumonia"
- "Type 2 diabetes mellitus"

Diagnosis:
